title: 107_hr3144
content: The "Investment Tax Credit Act of 2001" may be cited as the Investment Tax Credit. The Investment Tax Credit Act of 2001, also known as the Investment Tax Credit, amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow for an investment credit of 25 percent of the qualified investment for any taxable year. The qualified investment is the aggregate amount for that year. The Investment Tax Credit Act of 2001 allows for an investment credit based on the basis of new and used investment credit property placed in service during the taxable year. The applicable percentage is determined under specific rules outlined in the Internal Revenue Code. The Investment Tax Credit Act of 2001 allows for an investment credit based on new and used property. Certain rules from the Revenue Reconciliation Act of 1990 apply, and the credit is temporary for completed construction, reconstruction, or erection by the taxpayer. The Investment Tax Credit Act of 2001 allows for an investment credit based on new and used property. The credit is temporary for property completed by the taxpayer during an 18-month period, or acquired and placed in service during that time. The credit is limited to the basis attributable to construction, reconstruction, or erection, or to qualified investment with respect to qualified progress expenditures. The Investment Tax Credit Act of 2001 allows for a temporary investment credit for tangible personal property used in manufacturing, production, transportation, or research facilities. The Investment Tax Credit Act of 2001 provides a temporary investment credit for tangible personal property used in various activities, including bulk storage of commodities, elevators, escalators, agricultural structures, and storage facilities. The Investment Tax Credit Act of 2001 offers a temporary investment credit for tangible personal property, including storage facilities used in distributing petroleum or petroleum products. This credit applies to property with a useful life of 3 years or more and excludes other types of property. The Investment Tax Credit Act of 2001 provides a temporary investment credit for tangible personal property, excluding property eligible for energy or rehabilitation credits unless the taxpayer chooses to waive them. Certain progress expenditure and vessel rules apply. At-risk rules also apply. The Investment Tax Credit Act of 2001 includes at-risk rules for new and used investment credit property. Recapture rules are also amended to include certain property. The Investment Tax Credit Act of 2001 includes special rules for 3-year investment credit property, with specific percentage adjustments and exemptions for certain clauses. Conforming amendments are made to the Code regarding the investment tax credit. The Investment Tax Credit Act of 2001 includes special rules for 3-year investment credit property, with specific percentage adjustments and exemptions for certain clauses. Conforming amendments are made to the Code regarding the investment tax credit. Business credit attributable to the investment credit under section 48(c) can be carried to any taxable year before the enactment date. Amendments are made to section 1033(g)(3)(A) and the section heading for section 48 of the Code. The Investment Tax Credit Act of 2001 includes special rules for 3-year investment credit property, with specific percentage adjustments and exemptions for certain clauses. Conforming amendments are made to the Code regarding the investment tax credit. Business credit attributable to the investment credit under section 48(c) can be carried to any taxable year before the enactment date. Amendments are made to section 1033(g)(3)(A) and the section heading for section 48 of the Code. The table of sections for subpart E of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 of the Code is amended by striking the item relating to section 48 and inserting "Sec. 48. Other credits." Effective Date: The amendments apply to periods after the enactment date under rules similar to section 48(m) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986.
